TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) was originally an elite, invite-only conference held yearly in California. 
        It has since turned into a global organization famed for its videos "spreading ideas, usually in the form of short, 
        powerful talks (18 minutes or less)". 
        These presentations, known as "TED talks", have quickly become a cultural phenomenon and have been watched online billions of times.

Is TED elitist? In one sense, yes — we curate our speaker list and our TED Talks lineup very carefully. And we "curate" our audience at conferences to make sure we have a balanced, diverse group that can support our mission of bringing great ideas to the world for free.

TED's general message is deeply rooted in tech industry's narratives of individual genius and technological solutionism. 
        The TED talks (and associated videos) are carefully curated and produced. 
        They heroically stage a speaker giving a presentation in a condensed, often dumbed-down, but entertaining form. 
        The goal is to produce inspiration, and spread it onto the plebe so that said plebe would be transformed and in turn start changing the world.

American culture rides forward on stories about sudden fame and bold ascent—the singer who invents a new style of celebrity, the unknown actor rising with a quirky TV show, the kid who shapes a generation’s online habits from his dorm room. TED is a display case for such stories and, increasingly, the subject of them; the conference has grown famous for making its speakers famous, even as it claims to tread above the rough clod of celebrity.

"There just hasn't been a time when a girl in a remote village or a boy in a slum who is unemployed and angry and trying to figure out what to do with his life, can actually have, 18 inches from their eyeballs and plugged into their ears, some of the most inspiring speakers and mentors," [Chris Anderson, head of TED].

Giving a TED talk is for some of the speakers a life-defining moment. 
        The presentation is therefore meticulously prepared, with a carefully crafted narrative arch to play with the audience's affect. 
        The typical TED talk uses personal stories and various other gimmicks to try to build up towards some sort of enlightning / epiphanic ending.

Lior Zoref, an Israeli Ph.D. student, climbed onstage to rehearse what he called “the talk of my life.” [...] Zoref was nervous. He had spent the past few months preparing with an athlete’s focus for a talk of fourteen minutes. While the presentations that he usually gave were functional and evanescent, this one had to be a virtuosic feat, a summa of his work to date. “I’ve been practicing like I’ve never practiced,” Zoref had told me earlier [...] Now, with an hour left until his lecture, he was concentrating on minutiae and grace: the slow, assured sweep of his gaze across the audience; the way he strode across the stage; the timing of a joke. Everything else was muscle memory. By the time Zoref arrived in town, he said, he’d given his TED talk—to friends, to students, to his nonverbal one-year-old son, to anybody, really, who’d listen—more than four hundred times.
To me TED stands for middlebrow-megachurch-infotainment.

[TED] is not popularization, [it] is taking something with substance and value, and coring it out so that it can be swallowed without chewing. [...] The key rethorical device of any TED talk is a combination of epiphany and personnal testimony. [...] what does the TED audience hope to get from this ? Vicarious insight ? A fleeting moment of wonder ? A sense that maybe it's all gonna work out after all ? Spiritual buzz ?
The videos shown here are cuts from the most viewed TED talks of all time.
